unnormalised: RBI has issued a directive regarding mandatory linking of Aadhaar Nos. to all bank accounts by 31/12/2024. This initiative is aimed at enhancing transparency and curbing financial irregularities.
normalised: R-B-I has issued a directive regarding mandatory linking of Aadhaar Numbers to all bank accounts by thirty first december two thousand and twenty four. This initiative is aimed at enhancing transparency and curbing financial irregularities.

unnormalised: According to sources, customers must link their Aadhaar (UIDAI) to their respective bank accounts, demat accounts, and insurance policies. Banks are required to provide multiple channels for this process, including online banking, mobile apps, and branch visits.
normalised: According to sources, customers must link their Aadhaar (U-I-D-A-I) to their respective bank accounts, demat accounts, and insurance policies. Banks are required to provide multiple channels for this process, including online banking, mobile apps, and branch visits.

unnormalised: Financial institutions like SBI, HDFC Bank, and ICICI Bank have already begun sending reminders to customers with incomplete KYC details. Failure to comply may result in temporary suspension of account operations, as per the guidelines.
normalised: Financial institutions like S-B-I, H-D-F-C Bank, and I-C-I-C-I Bank have already begun sending reminders to customers with incomplete K-Y-C details. Failure to comply may result in temporary suspension of account operations, as per the guidelines.

unnormalised: Each customer is required to submit their 12-digit Aadhaar No. along with a self-attested copy of their Aadhaar card. This process will authenticate the customer's identity and prevent fraudulent activities such as money laundering and benami transactions. The unique Customer Identification Number (CIN) assigned to each account will also be linked for better tracking.
normalised: Each customer is required to submit their twelve-digit Aadhaar Number along with a self-attested copy of their Aadhaar card. This process will authenticate the customer's identity and prevent fraudulent activities such as money laundering and benami transactions. The unique Customer Identification Number (C-I-N) assigned to each account will also be linked for better tracking.

unnormalised: Experts suggest this move will streamline the financial system and improve the efficiency of government subsidy disbursements. However, concerns remain regarding data privacy and security, necessitating robust measures to safeguard customer information.
